general.headline: Intern at Embassy of Switzerland in Australia
general.description:
I am a driven and hard-working law and international relations student with a hunger for knowledge, a strong sense of social justice and a commitment to self-improvement.

I have a keen interest in the corporate sector, particularly in the intersection between corporate law and international business. In either an in-house or private practice capacity, I hope to pursue a career helping companies globalise and modernise so they can expand their operations and corporate networks, and better provide exemplary professional services in the evolving international marketplace.

I seek opportunities to intern and work in legal and other professional services firms. As someone who is receptive to new ideas, shows initiative and is an effective oral and written communicator, I could confidently meet the needs of any workplace.

Content was designed to cultivate and maintain an engaging and informative online presence with a large and continually growing outreach. This increased Carew Lawyers' business.

general.headline: Deputy Executive Director, Corporate and Project Finance at Transport for NSW
general.description:
Deputy Executive Director in the Corporate and Project Finance Branch (CPF) of Transport for NSW, which houses the transport cluster's centralised commercial and financing expertise.

CPF’s purpose is to originate and undertake financial, commercial and development activities and services in regard to high value, high risk, complex transactions and programs across the transport cluster. 

CPF’s key objectives include to:
- Leverage private sector expertise, innovation and financing capabilities to deliver public outcomes
- Develop and lead innovation in funding and financing models, commercial structuring and structured financing 
- Provide commercial, financial and risk management advice across the cluster 
- Provide origination, structuring and execution services across the cluster 
- Provide advice and execution on funding and financing strategies, unsolicited proposals, business cases, balance sheet management, procurement, commissioning, contestability and market engagement.

Transport for NSW is the centrepiece of the reshaped transport cluster. It is responsible for setting the strategic direction and guiding an extended network of public and private service delivery agencies to deliver improved transport outcomes. It is charged with planning and procuring transport infrastructure and services, improving customer experience, program administration, policy and regulation.

The infrastructure delivery program includes an unprecedented number of major projects, including Sydney Metro Northwest, Sydney Metro City and Southwest, Sydney Light Rail, NorthConnex, WestConnex, Parramatta Light Rail, Northern Beaches Bus Rapid Transit, North Sydney Freight Corridor, and others.

jobs.description:
Corporate and Project Finance (CPF) is a new branch within Transport for New South Wales (TfNSW) and houses the transport cluster’s centralised commercial and financing expertise.  CPF is one of three branches in the Finance and Investment Division that is headed by the Deputy Secretary Finance and Investment.
 
CPF’s purpose is to originate and undertake financial, commercial and development activities and services in regard to high value, high risk, complex transactions and programs across the transport cluster.
 
CPF’s key objectives include:

- Leveraging private sector expertise, innovation and financing capabilities to deliver public transportation and broader precinct related outcomes (including precinct renewal and property development);
- Developing and leading innovation in funding and financing models, commercial structuring and structured financing; and
- Providing advice and execution on funding and financing strategies, unsolicited proposals, business cases, balance sheet management, procurement, commissioning and contestability, and market engagement.
 
TfNSW is the centerpiece of the reshaped transport cluster. It is responsible for setting the strategic direction and guiding an extended network of public and private service delivery agencies to deliver improved transport outcomes. It is charged with planning and procuring transport infrastructure and services, improving customer experience, program administration, policy and regulation.
 
The infrastructure delivery program includes an unprecedented number of major projects, including Sydney Metro, Sydney Light Rail, NorthConnex, WestConnex, Parramatta Light Rail, Northern Beaches Bus Rapid Transit, North Sydney Freight Corridor, and others.

- Independent member of tender evaluation panel for the Sydney Light Rail PPP.

general.headline: Executive Director & Transaction Director WestConnex Sale at NSW Treasury
general.description:
Alex leads the sale of a 51% equity stake in Sydney Motorway Corporation, the concession holder of all three stages of WestConnex. WestConnex is Australia's largest motorway infrastructure project with a total capital budget of A$16.8 billion. The WestConnex Sale is part of the NSW Government's successful asset recycling program.

Prior to taking on his current role, Alex set up and headed the Corporate and Project Finance Branch in Transport for New South Wales. The branch combines the transport cluster’s centralised infrastructure financing expertise and leadership of transport-led urban renewal projects. The branch has 30 FTE. Corporate and Project Finance is a branch in the Finance and Investment Division that is headed by the Deputy Secretary Finance and Investment.

The key objective of the Corporate and Project Finance branch is to leverage private sector expertise, innovation and financing capabilities to deliver public transportation and broader precinct related outcomes including precinct renewal and property development.

jobs.description:
Paralegal duties at a busy commercial law firm in Sydney's CBD which specialises in commercial litigation, debt recovery, mediation, conveyancing and property law, contractual disputes, and insolvency. This experience has sharpened time management, attention to detail, stakeholder management, research, analysis, writing and communication skills.

Duties include:
• Applying knowledge of legislation and procedure when drafting accurate and clear advice to clients.
• Research, document review, proofreading and fact checking.
• Client management, including setting and meeting expectations, providing updates and advice, face to face, email and phone communication.
• Drafting legal documents, including claims, letters, advice, affidavits, and briefs to counsel.
• Diary and task management to managea busy workload and multiple cases, clients, and deadlines.
• Sharing training and knowledge with new staff, and showing enthusiasm to learn from senior staff.
• Court appearances and settlement negotiations.

Assisted the legal team at a not for profit organisation for Legal Aid qualified tenants facing eviction or issues of serious disrepair. (One to three days per week.)

• Conducted legal research (statutes, Westlaw, Lexis, and Practical Law) and wrote research memos.
• Attended interviews with clients and witnesses, and drafted letters of advice and witness statements.
• Drafted documents including letters of advice, statutory demands, and briefs to counsel.
• Liaised with clients and other side in person, via email and by phone.
• Created schedules of costs to send to other side during settlement negotiations.
• Court attendance, including delivering documents, answering counsel's questions on case, meeting client, witnessing court hearing, and updating instructing solicitor on the outcome.
• Prepared court bundles, and drafting cover letters to court and other side.

Shadowed barristers during Crown Court criminal cases. Observed scenarios including:

• Court craft, tactics and management with witness, defendant, solicitor, CPS, Police, and counsel.
• Questioning and cross-examination of adult and child witnesses, and closing statements to jury.
• Submissions to judge regarding evidence, witnesses, directions to jury and sentencing.

Assisted legal officers at a freedom of expression charity with research and preparation for international human rights and constitutional law cases involving journalists and bloggers. (Four days per week.)

• Researched human rights and freedom of expression legal authorities in various countries, using statutes, court databases, Westlaw, Lexis and scholarly articles.
• Wrote research memos on issues including attacks on journalists, press freedom, domestic interpretation of international law, protection of anonymous expression, and internet shutdowns.
• Drafted documents including witness statement and letter to European Court of Human Rights.
• Proofread/fact checked letters of intervention to international human rights courts.
• Supported three legal officers working on separate cases. Cross-communicated with all three to ensure duties were prioritised in the right order and conflicting deadlines were met.
• Research formed part of a submission to the European Court of Human Rights.

Evening shifts with The University of Law’s pro bono centre, facilitating the provision of legal advice.

• Checked conflicts of interest, interviewed clients and took detailed notes.
• Provided notes to a supervising solicitor, who allocated clients to the advice clinic.
• Signposted clients to relevant services where appropriate.
• Reviewed files and connected clients to an employment lawyer via conference call.
• Listened to advice, provided research and wrote attendance notes.

• Wrote for The Guardian on the Racial Discrimination Act and freedom of speech.

general.description:
A highly experienced senior finance executive with proven performance working in multi-disciplinary businesses, banking, and financial markets including debt capital markets. 

Consistently delivers successful projects for top 200 ASX companies, financial institutions and Government related entities. 

Strong focus on growing and developing relationships, negotiating and executing transactions and always delivering value to shareholders.

I have a strong track record in growing and developing relationships, negotiating and executing commercial transactions.
 
From airports to universities, infrastructure to utilities, property to ports, my job is to help organisations get the capital they need at the right price and at the right time.  
 
As a trusted adviser, I regularly work with c-suite executives, boards and treasury teams to formulate the finance strategies that will enhance their business.  My skill is understanding complex businesses and developing tailor-made solutions to source highly-competitive debt funding, locally and globally.

As part of this change agenda, the ATO is seeking to drive cultural and business shifts throughout the organisation.  The Deputy Commissioner, Public Groups works closely with the ATO Executive to effect these changes.

Jeremy has responsibility for two major streams within "Reinventing the ATO", firstly to improve the client experience for publicly listed businesses (across all taxes and ways they interact with the ATO), and secondly to ensure that the ATO provides tailored engagement and support to all taxpayers.

Chosen as an Australian Delegate for the 2017 University Scholars Leadership Symposium (USLS) to be held at the United Nations Conference Centre, in Bangkok, Thailand. The USLS, which is organised by Humanitarian Affairs UK and the UNDP, is a week-long Leadership Conference in Social Development for young leaders from all over the world.  The theme of the Symposium for 2017 was “Building LIFE, Giving HOPE”, and about 1,000 emerging world leaders in 70+ United Nations Member States attended this Youth Leadership Symposium at the UN in August 2017. Focusing on developing young leaders to bring social change, the delegates were able to achieve a higher level of engagement with the world’s largest humanitarian agency, the United Nations, through exposure to 12 UN agencies, who were able to showcase their works and lead workshop discussions themed based on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG). The purpose of the USLS was to instil a sense of social responsibility as well as to cultivate the attributes of selfless giving among our emerging world leaders. The young participants were able to learn what it means to give back to the community and be challenged to respond to the needs of the marginalized with works of kindness and unconditional service. Delegates had the opportunity to expand their professional network and understanding of world affair, and were motivated to use their knowledge and leadership skills to impact the communities in need.

As as an extension to my role as Gallery Assistant at Seva Frangos Art, in November 2012 I was further appointed to the position of Editorial Assistant of a Monograph on Timothy Cook, a leading contemporary Indigenous Artist published by the University of Western Australia Press. My primary responsibilities included the cataloguing and editing of images for use in the publication. This involved liaison with public, private, national and international collections as well as direct collaboration with Jilamara Arts & Crafts Association.

Acknowledgements (Page 175)
Editorial Team
Melanie Tannin, Editorial Assistant, Seva Frangos Art, Perth
“Working alongside an emerging art historian was a pleasure. Resourceful, committed and organised well beyond my own capacity at times, Melanie Tannin undertook the daunting task of all image permissions and details. Working closely with Jilamara Arts & Crafts Association, together they were able to overcome incomplete record systems and pursued every possible avenue in identifying, clarifying and confirming source material. It required Tannin’s persistence, patience and energy. Each step in carefully compiling the material was successfully undertaken with poise. Acquiring the large number of permissions has been her triumph, and belies her youthfulness. She approached the task with consideration, efficiency and lateral thinking, as much of the required information originated in remote Indigenous Australia but was ultimately scattered throughout the world.  Tannin willingly contributed to every aspect of the monograph with intelligence and original insights and graciously accepted the role of sounding board and secretary. Importantly, she is a fan of Timothy Cook and this was obvious in her sensitivity and mindfulness in responding to images and text.”

A real estate agent is an individual who is licensed to help clients sell and purchase residential properties. A junior is a developing real estate agent. 
These responsibilities include:
•	Discuss the method of sale, presentation of the property, costs and inspection times with vendors (sellers)
•	Estimate the current market price and suggest a reserve or minimum selling price by preparing a Comparative Market Analysis (CMA)
•	List details of land or buildings for sale and arrange the advertising of properties
•	Assess buyers' needs and locate properties for their consideration
•	Visit and show several sites and explain features of homes.
•	Advise on merits of properties and the terms of sale
•	Arrange legal agreements between vendors and buyers
•	Arrange finance and insurance. 
•	Make several telephone calls and in-person visits for presentations to existing and prospective customers 
•	Door knock 
•	Act as an intermediary in negotiations between buyers and sellers over property prices and settlement details, and during the closing of sales.
•	Work with loan officers, lawyers, and agencies to complete purchase.

One of the main responsibilities is to manage tenants. They are involved in all capacities, from finding the tenants and dealing with complaints to initiating evictions to ensure they are complying with the tenancy agreement and the vendor’s wishes. 

My responsibilities:
•	Screening Tenants- responsible for sorting through the prospective tenant applications to find the tenant that is the best fit for the property. Completing consistent screening process, including running credit checks and criminal background checks and finding those who will pay their rent on time, have a longer tenancy and create fewer problems.
•	Handling Leases- responsible for setting the length of the lease and making sure it has all the necessary provisions to protect the owner. This includes determining the amount of security deposit required. 
•	Handling Complaints/Emergencies- Deal with maintenance requests, noise complaints and have the necessary contacts to handle emergency situations. E.g. plumbers, electricians.
•	Handling Move Outs-when a tenant moves out, I am responsible for inspecting the property, checking for damages and determining what portion of the security deposit will be returned to the tenant. After move out, must ensure property is clean, repairing any damages and finding a new tenant. 
•	Dealing With Evictions –when a tenant does not pay rent or otherwise breaches the terms of a lease, must ensure we complete the proper way to file and move forward with an eviction.
•	Maintenance- performing preventative property maintenance to keep the property functioning in top condition.

Rufus & Coco is Australia's fastest growing and most awarded pet brand. Launched in 2008 by Anneke van den Broek, the company is re-shaping the pet industry by offering concise ranges of well-branded and packaged product which leverages the global phenomenon of people treating their pets as humans and part of the family.

The Rufus & Coco range currently includes vitamins, grooming and cleaning products, accessories and litter; and is aimed at all, from hamster to horse. With a team of dedicated pet lovers and a consumer centric focus, Rufus & Coco pride themselves on solving the needs of consumers with well thought out products that make a genuine difference in the lives of pets.

Rufus & Coco products are available in Australia through vets, selected pharmacies, health food stores, specialty pet stores, and supermarket giants like Woolworths, Coles and IGA.  The brand is also sold online as well as in countries like New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea and North America. Further overseas expansion is planned.

general.headline: Partner, Head of Private Client Dispute Resolution
general.description:
Specialities: Private Client Dispute Resolution ( shareholder, joint venture, partnership, trust, estate disputes) | regulatory disputes (direct and indirect tax, ACCC and ASIC)  | corporate governance dispute resolution | "white collar" malfeasance | financial services dispute resolution | general commercial litigation

I lead the firm’s Private Client Dispute Resolution practice which has a focus on shareholder, joint venture, partnership, trust, estate and governance disputes.  I also have experience in corporate and commercial law which is invaluable in negotiating and documenting the resolution of many shareholder, trust, joint venture and partnership related disputes.

As a partner at Hall & Wilcox, I provide my clients with commercial, practical and timely advice with a view to resolving disputes efficiently. I am an assertive and pro-active advocate for my clients' interests.

I also have considerable experience in the not-for-profit sector, including as a board member and trustee.

When not at work I enjoy running, music and catching up with friends and family.

general.headline: Senior Associate - Commercial Dispute Resolution at Hall & Wilcox
general.description:
Hamish is an experienced commercial dispute resolution lawyer based in Melbourne.

His experience extends to applications for urgent relief, appellate matters and defence of class actions. Hamish has acted in disputes involving breach of contract, corporations law, consumer law, equity, financial services, product liability, real property and intellectual property, in a range of industries including healthcare, technology, mining, government, pharmaceutical, property, retail and transport.

Hamish has appeared and instructed counsel in a range of Australian courts and tribunals and has also acted for clients in relation to complaints made to the Australian Human Rights Commission and has appeared for clients at inquiries conducted by the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC). In addition to court-oriented dispute resolution, Hamish has also acted for clients in several successful expert determinations and mediations of commercial disputes.

general.headline: Barrister and Mediator
general.company: Chair, Australian Dispute Resolution Advisory Council
general.description:
Jeremy is a Barrister at Denman Chambers in Sydney. He was called to the Bar in 1985 and appointed Senior Counsel in 2001. He was admitted as a Solicitor in 1978. Jeremy is also an accredited Mediator.

Jeremy's principal areas of practice as a Barrister include professional negligence (in particular, medical negligence), disciplinary proceedings and acting as Counsel Assisting Commissions of Inquiry, including Royal Commissions, Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC), Police Integrity Commission (PIC), Corruption and Crime Commission (CCC) (W.A.), Inquests and Special Commissions of Inquiry. Jeremy has practised in the areas of commercial, industrial, wills and probate and appeals.

Jeremy has appeared as Counsel Assisting in the following notable Inquiries.

*  Lindt Cafe Siege Inquest
*  CAA Seaview Royal Commission
*  Gretley Coal Mining Inquiry
*  Thredbo Landslide Inquiry
*  Collapse of NSW Grains Board (ICAC)
*  Orange Grove Inquiry
*  McGurk Tape Inquiry (ICAC)
*  Curti Taser Inquest
*  Inquiry into alleged assault by Mr Tripodi at NSW Parliament (ICAC)
*  Inquiry into aspects of the NSW Crimes Commission (PIC)
*  Inquiry into NSW Railway Corruption (ICAC) 
*  Perth Central TAFE Contracts Inquiry (CCC) (W.A.)
*  The Andrew Mallard wrongful murder conviction Inquiry (CCC) (W.A.)
*  Inquiry into Political Lobbying in NSW (ICAC)

In addition to his practise as a barrister and appearing for parties in mediations, Jeremy actively practises as a Mediator. He is an accredited Mediator with LEADR, the NSW Bar Association and National Standards for Accreditation of Mediators, Australia.

Jeremy has an extensive mediation practice and has mediated hundreds of commercial, equity, professional and medical negligence disputes. Notably, he was appointed on a joint Federal ministerial commission from the Commonwealth Attorney-General and Minister for Science and Personnel to mediate the long outstanding cliams from the 1964 HMAS Voyager-Melbourne collision.

jobs.companyName: Chair, Australian Dispute Resolution Advisory Council
jobs.description:
ADRAC  www.ADRAC.org.au is a national, unaligned think tank and thought leader in the field of dispute resolution. It has a council of 11 members drawn from sectors including banking, ADR membership bodies, Commonwealth public officers, the professions, academia, family support, mediation and arbitration. It aims to increase the use of all sound modes of dispute resolution. It publishes papers, makes submissions and examines the work, effectiveness of DR. 
ADRAC  is currently undertaking a major study of Conciliation as it operates across Australia. It is examining the teaching of ADR in Australian Law Schools and is preparing to make submissions to the Australian Law Reform Commission on its new Family Law reference.

general.headline: Head of Strategic Litigation Development at Grata Fund
general.description:
Lou Dargan is the Head of Strategic Litigation Development at Grata Fund.

She is as a human rights lawyer and advocate with experience working for reproductive justice in the US, transitional justice and victims' rights in Sri Lanka, and exposing child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church in Australia.

Before joining the Grata Fund, Lou worked for the South Asian Centre for Legal Studies (SACLS) in Colombo, Sri Lanka. Her work at SACLS focused on ensuring victims of the Sri Lankan civil war receive reparations for human rights abuses suffered during the conflict. 

Before moving to Sri Lanka, Lou completed an LLM at NYU, where she was an International Law and Human Rights Fellow and received the Jerome Lipper Award for distinction in International Legal Studies. At NYU, Lou was a member of the Reproductive Justice Clinic, where she advocated for the rights of pregnant and parenting women.

Previously, Lou was a senior lawyer at the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse, working on cases which exposed repeated failures by Catholic Church leaders to deal with abuse. Lou is also an experienced commercial lawyer, having worked for Clayton Utz in their litigation and international arbitration practice, before turning her focus to human rights work.

Lou was tipstaff to Chief Justice Allsop in 2011 and holds a Bachelor of Laws and a Bachelor of Arts with a politics major from Macquarie University. She received the University Medal in law and was ranked first in her graduating law class.

jobs.description:
At the Grata Fund, I am responsible for identifying, developing and supporting strategic litigation in Australia. Grata Fund works with the legal sector, academia and campaigners to incubate new strategic litigation in Australia on human rights, democracy and climate change. Grata Fund removes cost barriers to litigation via case financing. I develop new case leads and briefs, and draft and manage Indemnity and Guarantee Funding Agreements in funded litigation, as well as  managing partnership Memorandums of Understanding.

Grata Fund works to build broad campaign alliances around supported litigation to ensure lasting impact beyond the courtroom.

Mark Machaalani is an experienced litigator and commercial lawyer practising in the areas of commercial litigation, debt recovery, bankruptcy and insolvency, insurance law, property law, asset protection, retail and commercial leasing, the sale or purchase of business and conveyancing. Mark has extensive experience acting for a vast array of clients including multinational insurers, banks, blue chip corporations, small to medium business through to local councils and individuals. 

Mark represents clients in all Courts and Tribunals throughout Australia and is a talented advocate with a high success rate at numerous hearings and contentious motion hearings.

Mark provides legal advice to various businesses and entrepreneurs regarding maximising value, reducing risk and devising exit strategies. general.headline: Senior Associate at Wisewould Mahony Lawyers
general.description:
My name is Bernard Glass. I commenced working at Wisewould Mahony in 2010 and am predominantly employed in the WorkCover department Statutory Benefits team however my practice also extends to advisory work on behalf of the National Disability Insurance Agency. 

From day one Wisewoulds has been a great place to work. While it may be said the law is dry, the firm is dynamic and buzzing. It is filled with people who really enjoy what they do and are happy to share their breadth of experience and ideas to ensure the best outcome for clients. Working in such an environment it is easy come into the office each day to do your best. 

My main area of practice is Statutory Benefits which regularly has me up at the Melbourne Magistrates’ Court. We deal with all aspects of the Accident Compensation Act 1985 and Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013.   My practice also includes Judicial Review applications in the Supreme Court of Victoria. 

I recently completed a secondment with the Compensation Management Team at National Disability Insurance Agency. The role required statutory interpretation, drafting of policy and procedure as well as development of resources and implementation of standard operating procedures. 

As a litigator and legal adviser, I approach my practice with a keen eye for detail, a positive attitude and a willingness to share ideas and listen. I believe the best results are achieved through early and regular communication and open and honest advice.

general.headline: Senior Legal Counsel at BlackRock
general.description:
Andrew is a corporate lawyer in BlackRock’s Australian legal team, specialising in funds and financial services.  He supports BlackRock’s Australian and global business, including acting as Australian legal lead for the funds, alternatives / real assets, capital markets and financial technology (Aladdin) businesses.  

Andrew is experienced in a wide range of commercial transactions in the financial services and funds industry, including establishing, structuring, promoting and operating funds, as well as M&A and insolvency of managed investment schemes and regulatory advice of financial products and services.  

Andrew has over 15 years' private practice, in house, regulatory and legislative financial services legal experience.  His private legal practice experience at Minter Ellison and Corrs Chambers Westgarth advised leading asset managers and property funds.  He also has secondment experience at asset managers AMP Capital Investors and BT Investment Management and at the real estate investment manager, Cromwell Property Group.  Andrew also has regulatory and legislative experience in financial services at the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, starting his legal career in the Commonwealth Treasury advising on the regulation of financial services and the drafting of the Financial Services Reform Act.  
 
Andrew holds a Masters in Law from the University of New South Wales, a Bachelor of Commerce and a Bachelor of Laws from the University of Queensland and the Graduate Diploma of Applied Finance and Investment from the Securities Institute of Australia.

general.headline: Managing Partner at Norton Rose Fulbright Australia
general.description:
Wayne Spanner is Managing Partner of Norton Rose Fulbright Australia and a member of their Global Executive Committee.

He is an experienced litigator with a background in employment and labour law, having spent over 25 years in South Africa, the United Kingdom and Australia. Prior to being elected Australian Managing Partner, he was part of the Australian Executive for a number of years, serving as Head of the Australian Disputes Group and Global Head of the Employment and Labour Group.

Wayne’s leadership of the Australian Practice was recognised when he was named Lawyers Weekly Managing Partner of the Year in 2014.

During his time as Managing Partner, the Australian Practice has continued its growth to be one of Australia’s major legal teams, advising almost half of ASX top 100 companies and over 200 of Australia’s top 1000 companies.

In addition to his work with the firm, Wayne is a member of the Business Council of Australia and sits on their Labour Market, Skills and Education Committee and their Infrastructure and Sustainable Growth Committee.

A knowledge, information and training expert and and administrative/operational and strategic leader in the legal sphere. Working with other administrative directors and the firm's board, I led a team of legal and information management experts who, with me, were responsible for ensuring Henry Davis York's legal practitioners are supported by comprehensive library, precedents, knowledge management, advice and operational services to support all aspects of effective and efficient practice and quality client service. I brought highly developed people, technological, operational and cultural skills and understanding to my role. As an admitted legal practitioner, I advised on legal issues both internally and externally.

I worked closely with each practice group, with the managing partner and with the other business services of HDY (People & Development, Business Development, Finance and IT) on a range of knowledge and information management initiatives including document and data management systems, information sharing, library management, knowledge capture and reuse, and research. I oversaw the risk management function in the firm and was a founding member of the Innovation Committee.

I trained lawyers and clients in aspects of plain English, legal drafting and knowledge management, and was involved in the risk management and innovation initiatives of the firm. I ensured that the knowledge and information functions of the firm supported and enabled HDY's strategic plan, vision, values and goals and bring shared value to the firm and its clients.

I have over 17 years' experience in legal knowledge management and have also practised as a commercial lawyer in a leading international firm and been a secondary schoool teacher of English.

general.headline: Specialist Mergers & Acquisitions lawyer | Founder and Managing Director | Clarendon Lawyers | Corporate and Commercial
general.description:
Tony has significant expertise in public and private mergers and acquisitions (especially of a cross-border nature), joint ventures, equity offerings, private equity transactions, corporate law and general commercial matters, having worked exclusively in these areas for over 20 years. 

Tony is the trusted adviser to a range of prominent Australian and international corporate and private clients.

Tony was admitted to practice in 1996 and spent 4 years with Linklaters in Hong Kong between 2000 and 2004, where he focused on regional mergers and acquisitions as well as capital raisings.  

During his time with Linklaters, Tony worked extensively throughout Asia and advised
on some of Asia’s largest and most innovative deals, many of which involved multiple juridictions.

Shortly after returning to Melbourne, Tony co-founded the predecessor firm to Clarendon
Lawyers,  whose clients now range from large listed and private companies (including many foreign companies), private equity funds, family office groups and professional service firms to SMEs and individuals. 

In the 2017 and 2016 Doyles Guide in Australia, Tony was ranked as a "Pre-eminent" and “Leading Lawyer”, respectively, placing him in the top 6 M&A lawyers in Melbourne. In MergerMarket’s 2016 league tables, Tony was ranked 7th by volume of deals.

The firm’s vision is to be recognised as the leading Australian boutique corporate law firm (and as a real alternative to the top tier national law firms) in our core practice areas. The firm is focused on forming lasting partnerships with its clients and becoming their trusted adviser. 

Tony holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree and a Bachelor of Laws degree from the University of Melbourne.  He is admitted to practice in Victoria and Hong Kong.

Specialties: Private M&A, Corporate Law, Private Equity, Joint Ventures
